data.subtask_content: The devastation of the Great War had greatly destabilized Europe, and in many respects World War II grew out of issues left unresolved by that earlier conflict. In particular, political and economic instability in Germany, and lingering resentment over the harsh terms imposed by the Versailles Treaty, fueled the rise to power of Adolf Hitler and the National Socialist German Workers’ Party.

knowledges.knowledge_content: Versailles Treaty led to political and economic instability in Germany.

data.subtask_content: As early as 1923, in his memoir and propaganda tract 'Mein Kampf,' Adolf Hitler predicted a general European war. After becoming Chancellor of Germany in 1933, Hitler swiftly consolidated power, anointing himself Führer in 1934, and became obsessed with the idea of the superiority of the 'pure' German race. Hitler believed that war was the only way to gain the necessary 'Lebensraum' for the German race to expand.

knowledges.knowledge_content: Adolf Hitler predicted a general European war as early as 1923.
Hitler consolidated power and anointed himself Führer in 1934.

data.subtask_content: In the mid-1930s, Hitler secretly began the rearmament of Germany, a violation of the Versailles Treaty. After signing alliances with Italy and Japan, Hitler sent troops to occupy Austria in 1938 and annexed Czechoslovakia in 1939.

knowledges.knowledge_content: Germany's rearmament began in the mid-1930s.
Occupied Austria in 1938 and annexed Czechoslovakia in 1939.

data.subtask_content: In late August 1939, Hitler and Soviet leader Joseph Stalin signed the German-Soviet Nonaggression Pact. On September 1, 1939, Hitler invaded Poland from the west, leading France and Britain to declare war on Germany two days later.

knowledges.knowledge_content: German-Soviet Nonaggression Pact signed in late August 1939.
France and Britain declared war on Germany on September 3, 1939.

data.subtask_title: Major battles of World War II
data.subtask_content: Key battles of World War II included the Battle of Britain, Battle of Stalingrad, and the Normandy landings, which were pivotal in changing the tide of the war in favor of the Allies.

knowledges.knowledge_content: Key battles of World War II included the Battle of Britain, Battle of Stalingrad, and the Normandy landings.
knowledges.first_level_highlight: Battle of Britain, Battle of Stalingrad, Normandy landings

data.subtask_content: World War II proved to be the deadliest international conflict in history, taking the lives of an estimated 60 to 80 million people, including approximately 6 million Jews during the Holocaust.

related_subtask.title: Major battles of World War II

knowledges.knowledge_content: 60 to 80 million people lost their lives.
Approximately 6 million Jews were killed during the Holocaust.

data.subtask_content: The legacy of World War II included the spread of communism in Eastern Europe, a global shift in power to the United States and Soviet Union, and the beginning of the Cold War.

knowledges.knowledge_content: the beginning of the Cold War.
